Frank Drebin.Action: Notices a woman struggling with a baby carriage on stairs but chooses not to help, focusing on his job instead.
Nervously scans the train station, glances repeatedly between doors and clock, notices a woman struggling with a baby carriage but refrains from helping to focus on the job.
Rushes to help a Woman struggling to haul a baby carriage up the stairs.
Looks helplessly at Nordberg and Ed, silently asking for help, showing reliance on teamwork and concern.
Assists the Woman with the baby carriage even when confronted with danger (Mr. Big and his Goons).
Accidentally lets go of the baby carriage while firing at villains, causing distress to the mother.
Continues to fire at the attackers heroically despite chaos and distractions.
Notices and happily pockets a shiny quarter on the ground while still engaged in the fight.
Shoots the Hezbollah fanatic to protect the President, showing quick decisive action to prevent harm.
Horrified at babies in baby carriages being thrown about during the shootout, torn between duty and protecting the innocent.
Struggles between rescuing babies and continuing police work during chaos.
Firing on Postal Workers to stop them despite being overwhelmed.
Shows fear and vulnerability in nightmare, trembling after waking.
Refuses comfort and insists on staying awake despite wife's soothing.
Fires effectively on incoming Postal Workers, shooting them down rapidly.
Runs out of bullets and tries desperately to fire an empty gun.
Shows a worried look when out of ammunition and overwhelmed.
Wakes up in a cold sweat from a nightmare about being unable to stop crime post-retirement.
Declines Jane's affectionate offer to relax him, claiming a headache and showing mild panic.
Quickly hits another button to stop the Craftmatic Bed after it catapults him and Jane out the window.
Has a mild panic when adjusting the bed, causing an uncontrolled and chaotic reaction.
Greets Store Manager politely and remembers to bring coupons.
Accidentally grabs a woman's breast and is slapped.
Unaware of unraveling plastic bag roll and distracted by finding the bag opening.
Greets the store manager confidently and remembers the double coupon day, displaying some awareness and social competence.
Clips down a welding mask and attempts to separate shopping carts, showing initiative and a practical approach.
Accidentally grabs a woman’s breast while tapping melons, indicating a lack of awareness and social tact.
Yanks a whole roll of plastic bags off the roll without noticing, causing disorder and failing to manage the situation.
Struggles to find the opening of a plastic bag and then fails to bag a potato properly, dropping it through the bottom.
Accidentally places a baby in his cart, causing alarm but shows no hostile intent.
Observes a mother rush off with the baby-cart, watches after her quietly.
Attempts to move to a shorter checkout line politely but is beaten unfairly by others.
Does not react aggressively or cause conflict when pushed back in line.
Stops to help a woman whose purse is being snatched, ready to act despite missing his weapon.
Puts a roll of paper towels into his basket and mistakenly takes a baby in his cart, causing a mother to rush up and take the child away.
Tries to get to the check-out counter but a dozen people beat him in line, leaving him where he started.
Realizes the counter is closing and tries to switch to another counter, showing some awareness of the situation.
Reaches for his ice revolver instinctively when a thug attempts to snatch a woman's purse but finds it isn't there, so he stops and looks up.
Participates in a farewell gathering with colleagues, shares humorous and heartfelt remarks, and hugs Ed Nordberg who is moved to tears.
Ignores the store manager's urgent alert about a thief and responds distractedly, then walks away leaving the manager confused.
No direct actions or statements present in the excerpt to evaluate competence.
Admits to trying various methods (ointments, creams, books, things that vibrate) to address intimacy issues.
Responds defensively and shifts blame to Jane, saying 'Maybe it’s your fault.'
Tries to inject humor despite awkwardness of the situation, indicating some attempt at lightening the mood.
Responds quickly to the therapist’s blunt questions and awkwardly tries to defend himself and his efforts to overcome intimacy issues.
Makes sarcastic and defensive remarks during serious therapy session, e.g. jokes about the toilet seat or blames his wife.
Acknowledges trying various methods (ointments, creams, books, things that vibrate) to solve his problem, showing some initiative.
Misinterprets the seriousness of therapy and fails to engage constructively, instead deflecting blame and making jokes.
Expresses fear and vulnerability about having a child to Jane, comparing responsibility to a difficult job.
Engages in affectionate and playful pet names exchange with Jane.
Shows emotional sensitivity by tearing up watching a heartfelt TV soap opera scene.
Seems frightened by the idea of having a baby, expresses concerns in a somewhat humorous but apprehensive way.
Engages in playful pet names with Jane, showing emotional connection but not necessarily professional competence.
Absorbed in a TV soap opera while ironing with laundry nearby, showing distracted or unfocused behavior.
Emotionally moved by the TV scene, tear trickling onto the iron causing it to sizzle, suggesting sensitivity but also lack of attentiveness.
Welcomes Ed and Nordberg warmly, invites them in despite the mess, offers coffee and freshly frosted cupcakes.
Shows sincere concern for Bobbi and Jason's situation, expressing empathy about their problems.
Is attentive and hopeful when Ed mentions needing his help.
Makes cupcakes from scratch and seeks Ed's opinion, showing vulnerability and desire to please.
Asks to keep the photo of the woman involved in the investigation, showing a lighthearted or friendly attachment.
Greets Ed warmly with a soulful handshake and casual friendly conversation.
Offers a cigarette to Tanya Peters upon meeting her, showing a casual, approachable demeanor.
Focuses on the job and does not engage flirtatiously with Tanya despite noticing her attractiveness.
Focuses on the job instead of flirting despite temptation.
Engages in casual banter and uses humor while investigating.
Immediately takes charge at the crime scene by investigating the body and questioning witnesses.
Offers a cigarette to a key witness before questioning her, potentially risking professionalism.
Gladly offers help and makes polite conversation with Nordberg before dinner.
Reluctantly agrees to go undercover to help others despite personal plans.
Initially refuses to interrupt his personal evening plans for work.
Shows concern about protecting others (Jane and other Janes of the world), indicating a protective and caring attitude.
Initially resists returning to police work, showing reluctance and doubt about going undercover.
Considers the responsibility of protecting others and acknowledges his lapse in active duty, then ultimately agrees to go undercover.
Panics briefly about leaving the iron on, then continues calmly.
Accidentally hits a parking meter, causing coins to fly.
Makes an effort to disguise himself carefully to avoid recognition and maintain sincerity in his undercover role.
Does not understand the take-a-number machine and responds hesitantly.
Plays along with the nurse's number system confusion without complaint.
Engages politely with Dr. Kohlzak despite her skepticism.
Makes light, self-deprecating remarks about his condition (e.g., his arm hurting, his inability to keep up with his uncle).
Fails to understand the take-a-number machine and picks an invalid number
Follows Dr. Kohlzak as requested without hesitation or confusion
Provides vague and confusing answers about his problem to Dr. Kohlzak
Complies politely with Dr. Kohlzak's instructions despite discomfort, follows her to do paperwork.
Responds curtly to Dr. Roberts when told he is next, avoiding confrontation.
Avoids engaging Tanya in conversation to protect his cover, shielding his face and deflecting questions.
Tries to maintain composure and follow procedures during an awkward and unfamiliar medical test, completing the task despite discomfort.
Appears disheveled and exhausted after the specimen collection, indicating emotional or physical struggle under pressure.
Attempts to eavesdrop and blend in at the reception but is quickly recognized and confronted, suggesting a failure to effectively disguise or adapt.
Quickly shields his face and attempts to avoid further questioning that might blow his cover, showing presence of mind under potential risk.
Lightheartedly jokes about video titles with Dr. Roberts, engages in casual friendly banter.
Quietly searches through personnel files and takes personal information without permission.
Copies down Tanya's address using a lipstick on a handkerchief he took from an open purse.
Acts casual and tries to appear normal when caught by Tanya, joking about looking his best.
Quickly leaves and wipes lipstick off, avoiding direct interaction with Tanya.
Responds to Tanya's knocking and concern by saying he could use help.
Appears physically vulnerable and weak after a difficult day, showing human frailty.
Responds emotionally to Jane's affectionate and intimate gesture at home after a hard day.
Sits in wheelchair, appears physically debilitated and unable to speak clearly after an incident, holding a specimen cup with trembling hands.
Despite physical limitations and pain, manages to return home and slowly walk into the house where Jane prepares a romantic evening.
Tries to avoid intimacy by suggesting he soak in a tub for a few days, indicating discomfort but not rejecting Jane outright.
Opens up about his physical pain with a weak excuse to Jane, showing a form of guarded honesty despite the obvious lie.
Receives a sexy, playful advance from Jane and engages with it awkwardly but not coldly.
Avoids direct confrontation and hides truth from Jane about his injuries and work, which leads to distrust and anger.
Pours champagne down his pants hoping to numb pain, sits on ice to soothe himself, tries to avoid intimacy due to discomfort from injuries.
Lies about the cause of his lash marks, claiming he fell on a rake instead of admitting truth or explaining properly.
Tries to deflect Jane's anger and suspicion by inventing a story about another woman.
Hands Jane a handkerchief as she breaks down and dabs her eyes.
Admits love sincerely and tries to express himself despite the breakup.
Grabs Jane and kisses her passionately even though she is leaving.
Brings 'Frank's Never Fail Fudge' to share with colleagues, is greeted warmly by squad members.
Wistfully and painfully reacts to conversations about violence and action he misses, showing vulnerability.
Engages briefly with colleagues, but mostly keeps to himself while others do supportive tasks (dusting, cleaning).
Responds to the tribute of his retired uniform with a wistful smile and thanks his colleagues.
Opens up about Jane leaving him, showing vulnerability.
Tastes suspicious powder impulsively without concern for caution.
Engages cooperatively with Ted and Ed, listens carefully to the explanation and processes the information.
Expresses confusion openly and asks clarifying questions.
Jokes lightly when saying 'He’ll never fall for that one, Nordberg.'
Volunteers to go into Statesville Prison after a breakup, showing willingness to face danger despite personal pain.
Dismisses concern for his ex-wife Jane and focuses on personal desire for action.
Volunteers to go undercover into dangerous prison despite risks, showing willingness and confidence.
States that ‘You might end up dead’ is his middle name, showing bravado but possibly underestimating danger.
Admits he doesn’t know his wife Jane’s middle name, indicating possible personal or emotional neglect that could affect focus.
Mocks the surrounding prisoners by comparing them to violent gangs and sports fans, showing a sarcastic, somewhat dismissive attitude.
Attempts to assert toughness and make an impression by loudly mimicking prison slogans in a provocative manner (e.g., 'Power to the Brothers! Kill Whitey!'), risking confrontation.
Responds to threats with humor and sarcasm, deflecting hostility rather than escalating tension.
Refuses to show intimidation or fear when confronted by Rocco and Tyrone.
Maintains composure and uses wit when confronted by threatening inmates, even making jokes and clever retorts.
Fails to convincingly bluff about his identity; Rocco does not believe his story.
Shows confidence in a dangerous situation, not intimidated by thugs who try to threaten him.
Relies heavily on humor and sarcasm rather than demonstrating actual tactical or physical skills in a prison confrontation.
Writes a love letter to Jane despite knowing it may not change her mind, showing vulnerability and affection.
Hums a cheerful tune and enjoys showering with attention to personal grooming, suggesting a positive and friendly demeanor.
Offers to rub cream on Hairy Con's back in a friendly, playful manner.
Playfully taps Hairy Con’s nose and makes a lighthearted comment about his hairiness.
Talks confidently about staying active and skincare, offers to rub cream on Hairy Con's back.
Playfully advises Hairy Con to get a wax job for his hairy back, maintaining composure in an awkward situation.
Interacts with Hairy Con in a way that diffuses tension and commands attention, indicated by the silence and stopping of water.
Corrects Rocco politely ('Really well' instead of 'really good').
Engages in light-hearted banter with Rocco ('You got a dental plan?') and burps confetti.
Uses humor to ease tension and maintain camaraderie in a difficult situation (in prison).
Corrects Rocco's grammar from 'really good' to 'really well', demonstrating attention to detail and linguistic precision.
Proposes a better escape plan than the one they already have, showing initiative and confidence in problem-solving.
Burps and sprays confetti from his mouth during a serious discussion, indicating a lack of seriousness or professionalism.
No direct actions or statements by Frank Drebin present in the excerpt to evaluate competence.
Records a humorous, personalized answering machine greeting showing effort to connect with Jane.
Does not answer Jane's call in person, letting it go to voicemail, which makes Jane feel sad and cry.
Carefully plans and executes a tunnel escape with attention to detail and collaboration with Rocco.
Creates dummies of himself and Recco to fool the guards, carefully posed and smiling.
Cunningly hides dirt in mess hall plates and containers to aid in escape plan.
Attempts to tamper with the baseball field by filling home plate with dirt to stunt the runner's progress.
Waves the runner home and tampers dirt under his pant leg to create a mound at home plate, resulting in the runner being safe in a baseball play.
No evidence of awareness or effective reaction when dirt spills from his pant leg, causing alteration of the baseball field.
Has piles of dirt on head and shoulders during prison inspection, but guard ignores him, indicating his ability to blend in or remain unnoticed.
Races to tunnel in miner caps with lights and successfully escapes from prison with others.
Looks at the L.A. Coliseum and the kickoff, ducks down just in time to avoid being hit by the football.
Pops heads up in an open grave during a funeral, then quickly ducks back out of sight causing horror to the priest and mourners.
Huddles together with Rocco for safety when threatened by armed street toughs.
Mocks Rocco's mother by calling her an 'old hag' and making a crude joke about her taking one in the face.
Pretends to have amnesia and uses it humorously to defuse tension after Rocco pulls a gun.
Addresses Muriel with sarcasm, calling her son 'ruthless, sadistic, cold-blooded animal' in a mocking tone, despite her pride.
Internally acknowledges Muriel's coldness and distrust but does not confront her aggressively.
Calls the cabin a 'sweet set-up' and quickly tries to identify their target for action, displaying readiness and focus on the mission.
Calmly responds to Muriel pulling a gun on him by acknowledging the feeling but not escalating the conflict, showing emotional control and situational awareness.
Is distracted and stare-mouthed at Tanya in a revealing bikini, losing focus on the mission.
Misunderstands Tanya's sultry invitation and starts walking toward her, indicating confusion or poor judgment in the moment.
Uses a cover story to defuse a tense situation with Rocco and others, making a joking but benign comment about running away as a youth and being on 'Unsolved Mysteries' several times.
Sweats nervously but tries to maintain calm and honesty when questioned about being a cop, eventually admitting the truth.
Attempts to cover for an awkward situation with a quick witticism about talking about Rocco's mother.
Maintains composure and tries to explain his identity when confronted with guns pointed at him.
Is sweating and clearly uncomfortable when threatened with guns pointed at him.
Uses humor and odd references (milk carton, Unsolved Mysteries) to defuse tension and convince others he is not a cop.
Fails to appear confident or convincing initially, requiring reassurance.
Tries to send a message tied to a pigeon to get help despite difficult circumstances.
Reacted with stunned surprise at Muriel's unexpected long kiss and disdain afterward.
Plays chess casually and responds coolly when Tanya approaches, showing a friendly and easygoing demeanor.
Grabs Tanya’s wrist while joking about her coming on to him, acknowledging her affection but also noting a problem.
Responds with confusion when Tanya asks if he’s Jewish, demonstrating openness but also slight awkwardness.
Attempts to send a message using a pigeon when isolated without phone, showing initiative.
Fails to properly release the pigeon; it hits a window fan causing a commotion.
Contemplates next move at a chessboard, but moves a pawn like in checkers, indicating misunderstanding of the game.
Maintains composure and uses flirtation to engage Tanya despite awkward situation.
Accepts and reciprocates Tanya’s affection by embracing and kissing her warmly.
Feels tense and expresses uncertainty about the future, showing vulnerability and openness.
Quickly kisses Jane to stop her from calling out, catching her off guard, possibly manipulative or inconsiderate.
Offers to drive a dizzy dame to the nearest bus depot.
Makes light-hearted, teasing remarks during a marital spat with Jane.
Shrugs off gang's unwritten law to remove the woman, showing reluctance to harm Jane.
Uses quick physical action to prevent Jane from calling out his name and gain control of the situation.
Responds with sarcastic, dismissive remarks in a tense situation, not diffusing the tension constructively.
Attempts to apply some logic about hostage-taking and the value of a hostage, showing some tactical awareness.
Shrugs off an important gang law and fails to provide a clear decision about Jane's fate, showing indecision or lack of leadership.
Wraps rope around Jane's ankles to secure her, calmly interacting despite tense situation.
Uses kissing as a ruse to gather information to protect Jane.
Shows a tear trickling down his cheek looking at Jane's ring inscription 'Here. Love, Frank.'
Oblivious to Jane's fall after she stands while trussed up.
Receives and responds to secret glances from Tanya, engaged but neutral.
Exchanges worried looks with Jane after witnessing destruction.
Comments 'Very impressive...' in a way that shows understated concern rather than detachment.
Pretends to put Jane in the trunk in a playful manner, sharing a conspiratorial moment with her.
Disables the car engine to prevent escape, indirectly protecting others.
Pretends to put Jane in the trunk in a ruse to deceive the others.
Disables a car by removing the distributor cap and spark plug wires, effectively immobilizing it.
Pins Muriel in the car windows with her head stuck through the sunroof to restrain her.
Acts confidently by announcing himself as 'Frank Drebin, Police Squad' directly to a threatening character.
Tries to help by calling Police Squad to intervene.
Rolls eyes and dismisses immigrant cab drivers who don't understand him.
Politely persists when stopped by security, attempting to explain identity sincerely.
Says 'Frank Drebin, Police Squad' confidently despite odd situation with Muriel wedged in sunroof.
Claims unusual events are normal for him, indicating experience and calmness.
Tries multiple cabs and interacts with different cab drivers to get help, showing persistence and resourcefulness.
Rolls eyes and quickly abandons trying to communicate with cabs speaking unknown languages, showing practical judgment.
Fails to gain entry at Shrine due to security ignoring his badge and claim, indicating limited influence or authority.
Apologizes politely to the gagged people in the bushes and reassures them their passes will be returned by tomorrow.
Attempts to attend the Academy Awards undercover to stop a threat, showing dedication and teamwork.
Tries to act casual with Jane while being checked by security, showing a lighthearted and cooperative attitude.
Ponders where the bomb could be; correctly deduces it must be in one of the envelopes on stage after discussion with Jane.
Forgets his good pair of binoculars at the cabin, which would have helped his observation in the current situation.
Looks around sheepishly with Jane as people stare at them; Jane smiles apologetically at a sour woman indicating some social awareness and consideration.
Focuses intently on finding envelopes backstage to possibly prevent further announcements, showing a sense of responsibility and urgency.
Comments on the large number of envelopes and participates cooperatively with Jane in checking them carefully.
Quickly identifies the urgent need to get to the envelopes before more are opened.
Feels overwhelmed by the large number of envelopes and new categories.
Carefully checks each envelope methodically with Jane.
Notices potentially dangerous envelope and warns Jane about it, attempting to prevent harm.
Knocks out Phil Donahue with a karate chop and takes his place without explaining or apologizing, potentially causing confusion.
Sees Raquel choking and immediately applies the Heimlich Maneuver to help her.
Applies the Heimlich maneuver promptly when Raquel is choking, preventing a potential disaster.
Struggles physically with the unstable staircase and tumbles down the stairs, showing lack of physical coordination or control in this situation.
Attempts to smoothly manage the awards show by reading from the teleprompter and engaging with Raquel and the audience despite being out of his element.
Shows some awkwardness and confusion while reading the teleprompter and interacting with others on stage.
Understands teleprompter cues and starts reading his lines confidently at the awards show.
Continues reading despite being unsure about the teleprompter content and seems at a loss momentarily.
Stalls to prevent Raquel from opening a suspicious envelope, showing concern for safety.
Earnestly calls for people worldwide to send good thoughts to promote kindness, despite confusion about the leader's name.
Expresses concern for the hungry and proposes a bizarre, insensitive solution to feed cats by butchering porpoises, showing a lack of empathy towards animals and poor judgment.
Suggests skinning cats to use their fur to keep hundreds warm.
Peeks into the envelope and reassures Raquel by saying 'It's okay...'
Worriedly searches the crowd for Jane after Raquel has an accident
Turns over garbage cans and causes harm to Security, then runs away
Taps a guy on the shoulder to point out snot on his shoe, then karate chops him and takes his top hat and cane.
Joins the dancers on stage, attempting to blend in and mimic their dance moves, despite awkwardness.
Swinging his cane around unwittingly poking and hitting others, causing them pain though likely unintentionally.
Tossing Pia into the air, spinning her and engaging in an energetic dance with her.
Accidentally lets go of Pia's wig, causing a minor mishap on stage.
Swings cane around, unwittingly poking and hitting people in sensitive areas, causing chaos on stage.
Engaged in dance number, tossing Pia and spinning her, but accidentally lets go leading to comedic mishap.
Does a goofy dance on stage showing playful and friendly behavior despite chaos.
Sweeps Pia up onto his shoulder to help her ascend the lift, attempts to support her.
Drops Pia when unable to hold her up anymore.
Goes by doing a crazy legs dance, accidentally kicks a guy in the stomach, causing distraction.
Leaps onto the hydraulic lift with Pia and sweeps her onto his shoulder in an attempt to assist her escape.
Unable to hold Pia up and drops her from the hydraulic lift.
Sees an opportunity to escape and makes a daring leap off the lift, escaping from security.
Quickly checks he hasn't been followed and slams the door shut behind him, showing caution and focus on his task.
Grabs Tanya suddenly and pins her against the wall demanding answers, using forceful and somewhat rude language ('cherry cakes').
Responds to Tanya's 'I love you' with dismissal and sarcasm ('Wrong answer'), showing lack of sincerity and tolerance.
Accuses Tanya of lying but listens to her plea and responds with surprise and discomfort rather than anger; does not retaliate aggressively.
Accepts an unexpected kiss from Tanya, showing openness to affection despite the awkward situation.
Interrupts formal ceremony by rushing onstage and overwhelming himself with the tuba, indicating vulnerability and lack of pretension.
Accurately deduces the location of the bomb ('It’s in the Best Picture envelope').
Fails to resist distraction and seduction by Tanya, allowing himself to be manipulated.
Reacting to Tanya’s disrobing by running away abruptly rather than maintaining professionalism or control.
Rushes onstage in an attempt to intervene but ends up vomiting into a tuba, causing a public scene.
Nordberg shows concern for Frank, asking about Tanya and Rocco and trying to calm him; Frank looks ill and struggles but tries to maintain composure.
Staggers off stage looking disoriented, needing assistance from Nordberg.
Tries to gather himself and respond politely despite apparent illness.
Appears physically unwell and struggles to maintain composure in a professional setting.
Looks for a way to dispose of the loaded envelope, attempts to act to prevent harm in a dangerous situation.
Rushes Rocco and wrestles his wrist to prevent him from using the gun, showing concern for others' safety.
Looks around for a way to dispose of the loaded envelope.
Rushes Rocco when he is momentarily diverted, attempting to disarm him.
Struggles to wrestle the gun from Rocco but Rocco easily switches hands and the gun goes off.
Tries to avoid harm to Jane by agreeing to Rocco's demands and telling him not to harm her.
Refuses to pull out the bomb despite Rocco's threats, prioritizing others' safety.
Uses humor to defuse a tense hostage situation, aiming to stay calm under pressure.
Disarms the antagonist to protect others, showing protective and trustworthy behavior.
Convinces Ed not to worry and says 'I know what I'm doing.'
Attempts to use the same trick as Rocco by grabbing a rope and firing a gun upward, but miscalculates and is thrown onto his back, rocketing into the rafters.
Struggles desperately to free himself from a dangerous predicament to save Jane.
Remains the focus of Jane's declaration of love and admiration, reflecting his sincere relationships.
Drops into frame unexpectedly behind the antagonist while dangling upside down from a rope.
Flops around struggling to free himself from the rope tether by his ankle, appearing desperate and uncontrolled.
Endures an embarrassing public moment while hanging by his teeth, rolling his eyes and wishing the world wasn't hearing it.
Lets go of the rope and accidentally falls on an antagonist (Rocco), disrupting him.
Responds to Jane's affection sincerely and tenderly, putting her ring back on her finger, sharing loving kisses, and expressing desire to never be apart.
Slides down rope to stage with Jane and handles the moment smoothly, appearing heroic and confident.
Focused on intimate moment with Jane, not noticing surrounding crowd and chaos.
Rushes into the delivery room to support Jane, filming the birth and encouraging her to breathe.
Expresses shock and accuses Nordberg upon seeing the unexpected race of the baby.
Rushes into the delivery room with Nordberg, uses a camcorder to record the birth, and tries to support Jane by encouraging her to breathe.
Mistakenly assumes the baby is Jane's because of the mixed racial identity, expresses surprise and suspicion at Nordberg, pulls a gun on him without further investigation.
Shows anger and aggression while pursuing Nordberg, firing his gun wildly.
Son is tenderly cradled by Jane, indicating a family connection but Frank himself is not shown interacting warmly in this excerpt.
Continues pursuit of Nordberg while firing his gun wildly, despite being angry beyond reason.
